Communication 1","description":"

This course introduces representation techniques for landscape architecture that facilitate clear and concise communication of ideas. Plan, section and elevation drawings, hand lettering, perspective drawing and experiments in different rendering styles will be explored and employed to communicate your design ideas.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e297692bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619d4","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Sketchbook - Drawing Studies","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Undertake a variety of drawing studies and explorations of freehand graphic media to record, interpret and express what students observe in class and in the field.

Feedback is via written rubric marking guide.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e297692bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619d5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2697692bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619d8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Orthographic Studies","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Produce a set of presentation quality drawings using landscape architectural drafting conventions to represent plans, sections, elevation and axonometric.

Feedback is via written rubric marking guide.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ea97692bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619d5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2e97692bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619da","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"A1 Digital Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Produce an A1 presentation board which displays orthographic drawings with a series of diagrams and a supporting planting and materials palette.

Feedback is via oral delivery at presentation and a follow up written rubric marking guide.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e297692bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e697692bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619ef","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial Exercises","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Oral feedback during tutorials.

contentlets.description: This course introduces representation techniques for landscape architecture that facilitate clear and concise communication of ideas. Plan, section and elevation drawings, hand lettering, perspective drawing and experiments in different rendering styles will be explored and employed to communicate your design ideas.

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND1322 - Urban Landscape Design Seminar","description":"

The course is an introduction to the analysis and design of urban landscapes, focusing the spatial quality, scale and texture of cities. Urban form is studied as a complex system of building types, civic space, infrastructures and ecosystems. Students critically analyse cities as expressions of human responses to environmental conditions and natural processes. The course also emphasizes the role of landscape architecture and planning in sustainable/green cities. Assessment tasks include quizzes, national and international case study analysis and a research essay.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9797a92bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619fb","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"A2 - The urban landscape atlas (Group work)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Urban analysis

The students will produce an Urban Landscapes Atlas as a bound collection of maps of urban landscapes in Australia and around the world.  Each team will focus on the comparison of five cities and examine their urban development in relation to pre-existing landscapes and environmental conditions, including local climate, topography, hydrography, latitude, orientation, etc.

Assignment A2 will be handed over and uploaded online on Moodle in PDF format. Final deliverables will receive written feedback and rubrics on Moodle. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9797a92bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9f97a92bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9f97a92bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619fc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1f97e92bdb61fc50be4672f5f3961902","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"A1 - In-class Quiz (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Theory and practice of urban landscape design

Assignment A1 is covering the activities, lectures and readings in tutorials T0, T1 and T2. Additional materials will be provided during class to integrate the tutorials. 

This assignment is aimed at retrieving and refreshing your meta-knowledge on landscape architecture history and city planning from previous courses.

A1 will be marked online on the base of the results of a multiple-choice and open-end questions quiz.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9797a92bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619fc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9f97a92bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619fb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9397a92bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619ff","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"A3 - Places in urban landscapes (Individual task)","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Illustrated Research essay

The objective of assignment A3 is to produce an illustrated essay to integrate the Urban Landscape Atlas. The essay will be based on the development of previous research findings assignment A2.

The essay will contain images, maps, diagrams and describe, argue, discuss hypothesis and research questions. Essay’s content: Min 1500 max 2000 words, excluding references, footnotes (if any), captions, tables, and titles. Refer to tutorial T6, T7 and T8 for this section.

Assignment A3 will be uploaded on Moodle and will receive written feedback and rubrics.

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND1351 - Landscape Performance and Management","description":"

This course explores the performance of landscape architecture in terms of delivering diverse cultural, social and environmental benefits. These landscape values and benefits are explored through four sub-themes; remediation and restoration, landscape policy and governance, culture and conservation and urban and regional landscape systems. Assessment activities include a research essay and focus on developing the knowledge and skills required to support the design and management landscapes for change and performance, particularly in terms of social and environmental benefits.

of Arts, Design and Architecture","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"LAND1421 - Thesis Foundation","description":"

The first half of an optional and specialised individual study, enabling students to gain or extend their in depth knowledge and understanding of a particular aspect of landscape architecture. A thesis proposal, including the nomination of a supervisor, must be approved by the Program Head by the end of Session 3 Year 3. The thesis is approximately 12,000 to 15,000 words in length. Each student conducts the required research, organisation of material and writing under the guidance of their supervisor. The thesis also includes the preparation of illustrative material and completion of all necessary references and bibliography, before the submission of the final manuscript for assessment. The manuscript is assessed by two readers and returned with corrections noted, so that a final digital copy of the thesis can be submitted.

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND1422 - Landscape Thesis","description":"

The second half of an optional and specialised individual study, enabling students to gain or extend their in depth knowledge and understanding of a particular aspect of landscape architecture. This course follows succesful completion of LAND1421 Thesis Foundation. The thesis is approximately 12,000 to 15,000 words in length. Each student conducts the required research, organisation of material and writing under the guidance of their supervisor. The thesis also includes the preparation of illustrative material and completion of all necessary references and bibliography, before the submission of the final manuscript for assessment. The manuscript is assessed by two readers and returned with corrections noted, so that a final digital copy of the thesis can be submitted.

An introduction to the practice of landscape architecture, its scope and potential with a focus on current issues and practices. Topics include professional ethics, client relationships, consultancy, project procurement, contracts and project management. Course delivery is supported with guest lectures from industry leaders, organised and facilitated by student teams. All students are required to have completed their Design Office work experience before receiving their final mark for the course. Students must pass all assessments to pass the course.

contentlets.description: An introduction to the practice of landscape architecture, its scope and potential with a focus on current issues and practices. Topics include professional ethics, client relationships, consultancy, project procurement, contracts and project management. Course delivery is supported with guest lectures from industry leaders, organised and facilitated by student teams. All students are required to have completed their Design Office work experience before receiving their final mark for the course. Students must pass all assessments to pass the course.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2101 - Landscape Studio 1 - Design Fundamentals","description":"

This course provides students with an introduction to design elements, principles and strategies as they relate to the practice of Landscape Architecture. Design thinking delivered in this studio is the foundation for all subsequent design studios in the program. Studio activities focus on design exploration using various modes of analogue and digital representation. Assessment activities develop the knowledge and ability to design small sites for human activity by working with fundamental landscape elements: landform, plants, and water. Students are encouraged to develop their designs by processes of testing, discussion and revision. Communication skills developed in this studio are introduced in the prerequisite course BENV1010 and the parallel course in Term 2, LAND1142 Landscape Architecture Design Communication 2.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0bb7e16bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619dd","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2B: Concept design proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

In Part B, students will respond to their analysis undertaken in Part A and develop a concept proposal. The concept proposal will outline their design principles, and communicate through drawing and model making their design response to the brief. Students will present their final design proposal verbally to their peers in the class.

Verbal and written summative feedback with grade rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"03b7e16bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619ec","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"03b7e16bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0bb7e16bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619eb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0bb7e16bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619ec","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0bb7e16bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619f7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: A Landscape Imagined","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

This assessment challenges students to make an imagined landscape. The departure point for the project is a small text/novella and the landscape architect site that was assigned to each student in LAND2121 (Introduction to Landscape Architecture) in T1.

Students will use model making to explore landscape form and spatial qualities. The sketch models will evolve, through several iterations, before students resolve their schemes through final, scaled drawings of their imagined landscape.

Written summative feedback with grade rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"03b7e16bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0bb7e16bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619eb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0bb7e16bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619ec","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"83b7e16bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619ee","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2A: Site analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

This assessment is in two parts (A &B) and is centred on the political power of landscape, not only to reshape land but to instigate changes in social and spatial practices in order to relate to the bigger relationships between people, culture and their environments. 

In Part A, students interpret and analyse a site, at a range of scales, through a series of drawings, diagrams and images. These drawings effectively communicate the opportunities and constraints contained within the site, as well as the temporal qualities and attributes that magnify the experience of the site.

Written summative feedback with grade rubric.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2102 - Landscape Studio 2 - Design Process","description":"

An introduction to site design and design process. A number of small-scale projects will allow exploration of design process through site planning, the use of historical precedent and design generation. Studio based projects will be supported by theoretical readings.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a4c7656bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619fe","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 2 Exploring the Concept","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

 

Interpreting and designing through observation and representation. A small-scale landscape design intervention. This project includes examining and reinterpreting graphic representation techniques, iterative drawing and model making as core design process practices. This iterative work is intended to be explorative, imaginative and carefully crafted.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e0c7656bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e0c7a56bdb61fc50be4672f5f3961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e8c7656bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e8c7a56bdb61fc50be4672f5f3961900","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b8c7a56bdb61fc50be4672f5f3961910","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 3 Path, Prospect and Place","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

 

Investigating and assembling activities and landscape. The final design project introduces a programmatic brief informing further design process, building on the conceptual work undertaken in the first and second projects. Various functional and conceptual components will be analysed, explored and assembled in a coherent design proposal for a reimagined public space.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e0c7656bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e0c7a56bdb61fc50be4672f5f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e0c7a56bdb61fc50be4672f5f3961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e8c7656bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e8c7a56bdb61fc50be4672f5f3961900","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ecc7a56bdb61fc50be4672f5f3961902","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 1 Discovering Place","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

 

Personal responses to the qualities of the place will be discovered and documented. Site inventory and context analysis will be undertaken based on landscape architecture theory as a way of framing site responses, captured through a range of graphic techniques.  This project forms the foundation for projects 2 and 3.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e0c7656bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e0c7a56bdb61fc50be4672f5f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e0c7a56bdb61fc50be4672f5f3961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e8c7656bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e8c7a56bdb61fc50be4672f5f3961900","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"fcc7a56bdb61fc50be4672f5f3961909","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/LAND2102.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}
contentlets.description: An introduction to site design and design process. A number of small-scale projects will allow exploration of design process through site planning, the use of historical precedent and design generation. Studio based projects will be supported by theoretical readings.
contentlets.title: Landscape Studio 2 - Design Process

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2121 - Introduction to Landscape Architecture","description":"

This course provides an overview of landscape architecture as a practice, a profession and an academic discipline in its own right and in relation to other built environment disciplines. It includes the study of contemporary landscape architecture as a design field and creative force in shaping the built environment and addressing issues relevant to the environment and sustainable development.

This course is a survey of the history of gardens and designed landscapes from Ancient Greece through to the twentieth century. The course engages students in a critical analysis of cultural landscapes through the investigation of philosophical, aesthetic and social aspects of landscape architecture and garden art in the Eastern and Western traditions.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2142 - Landscape Architecture Communication 2","description":"

This course encourages students to develop a personal vocabulary of landscape representation techniques to facilitate the development and communication of design ideas.  Students develop a range of communication techniques including 3D visualisation (perspective sketches, montages, 3D and terrain modeling), colour rendering, and the use of digital media generally.  The course introduces Computer Aided Design in 2D and 3D.  The integration of these outputs will be explored across the digital suite.  The course builds on and links with the physical media skills learned in LAND1141 to develop a high level of spatial and graphic thinking.

Students will engage with the layout and typography tools of InDesign to create an engaging and cohesive presentation of studio work from LAND2101

Feedback is via written rubric marking guide.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2151 - Landscape Analysis","description":"

This course focuses on the observation and interpretation of the environment with a particular emphasis on the interrelationship between geology, climate, soils, hydrology, flora, fauna and humans.  Concepts of ecology, sustainability, biodiversity, habitat fragmentation, and landscape ecology are introduced.  Students review the fundamental characteristics of a range of regional ecosystems, and analyse human modification of the environment.  Through a range of assessment tasks, students record and analyse the landscape using inventory, survey, mapping, reporting and presentation techniques associated with the practice of landscape architecture.  The course involves several excursions to local sites.  Students are asked to contribute to the cost of these excursions.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"47d76d6bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619f1","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Kurnell Annotated Sketchbook","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

This is an annotated sketchbook detailing your reading of the Yena Track. It records your reading of the Yena Track, integrating your own descriptive text with your drawings and maps.

 

The aim is to develop an understanding through observation and sketching of the interplay of geology, soil types and plant Communities from coastal sandstone edge across the Holocene Sand dunes to Botany Bay and to develop the ability to record and describe landscapes.

 

  1. mapping of the site with an inserted context map
  • original sketches of each plant community studied with annotations to highlight specific details
  • a transect of the track noting landform, geology and soils with each stop identified

 

Course learning outcomes

This assessment develops your ability to:

 

  • Describe in general terms the significant attributes of the landscapes and vegetation communities of the local region
  • record, organise and communicate your field observations and research in an effective and meaningful manner;

 

Assessment Criteria:

  • Accuracy of description and demonstrated knowledge of the Kurnell Peninsula
  • Ability to clearly and accurately record, organize and communicate relevant information in the required formats
  • Adherence to academic protocols
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"47d76d6bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"47d76d6bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4fd76d6bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619f1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4fd76d6bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619f2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0bd7ad6bdb61fc50be4672f5f3961913","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"State of catchment Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This report is an information signboard designed to educate visitors to Lake Parramatta about the vegetation communities and topography associated with the Lake and its surroundings. It will include analysis of landform, hydrology, microclimate, geology, soils and vegetation communities.                                                    

 

  • The focus is the preparation of an educational tool about Lake Parramatta Reserve and environs. 
  • The poster presentation aims to develop students’ abilities to gather and synthesize information collected on the field excursion It also furthers skills in desktop analysis and teamwork.
  • The poster will include graphic material created by the students including: an A3 transect, location maps, slope, aspect and elevation analysis. This work begins in the tutorials AHEAD of the excursion.  (Each student will submit all the completed maps to their tutors).
  • The poster will include selected examples of each group member’s work.
  • It will provide an opportunity to explore large scale layout and deciphering a hierarchy of headings and information. The use of colour and graphics will require careful consideration.
  • The poster will involve research using primary and secondary sources and must be properly referenced.

 

Assessment Criteria

Description of a landscape

  • Correct terminology
  • Clear and concise
  • Correct graphic language

Use of inventories, maps and other surveys

  • Accurate identification of plant communities and their features
  • Effective and accurate mapping of hydrological and topographical features
  • Accuracy and quality of a landscape transect, summarising landform, geology, soils, vegetation communities and aspect

Record, organize and communicate

  • Clear textual and graphic communication in an A1 poster format
  • Clear and effective layout and organization of a A3 folded brochure

Analysis of a landscape

  • Thorough, relevant and accurate

Academic Protocol

  • All material referenced accurately
  • All work produced by student; integrity

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2152 - Plants and Design","description":"

This course focuses on the aesthetic and functional aspects of plants in site-specific design contexts. The course introduces basic botanical and horticultural concepts, and criteria for plant selection including aesthetic, functional and ethical. Students develop a vocabulary of planting elements, and an ability to design with plants to achieve specific spatial qualities. Principles of planting design are explored through the study of historic and contemporary landscape architectural designs. Students prepare a conceptual planting design for a landscape space.


The course involves excursions to local sites, and students are asked to contribute to the cost of these excursions.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a0e7ed6bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619f6","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Planting Design Analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Analysis of 2x areas of a built landscape project to compare the factors influencing the planting design and to assess the design elements of the designs.

Aim: To explore planting design through the analysis of existing planting schemes.

Procedure: Students will prepare plan and section analyses of two existing planting schemes. Time will be allocated during tutorials for the development of the drawings.

Scope of Work: Students will identify the plants and planting elements of two planting designs and analyse each design in accordance with specified criteria. Students will illustrate their findings with fully annotated plans, sections and perspectives.

Assessment Criteria:
• Accurate identification of plants species and planting elements
• Effective textual and graphic documentation of each planting design (correct terminology; correct application of concepts and principles delivered in lectures and readings)
• Accurate and effective analysis of aesthetic, cultural and functional attributes of the planting elements and the planting design
• Originality of work

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a0e7ed6bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a8e7ed6bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619f7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"60e7ed6bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619fa","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online and self-guided exercises","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Planting analyses, plant identification and development of skills for quick sketches.

Aim: To develop acuity and confidence in planting design and graphic communication and to develop planting design from theory.

Procedure: Activity sheets will be distributed in the tutorial that require students to listen to a podcast or read a paper. Students will prepare a planting design response to these resources. The objective of these exercises is to develop the agility to explore planting design intuitively.

Scope of Work: Exercises will include the preparation of an A4 sketch for discussion in the tutorial.

Assessment Criteria:
• Application of design principles learned in the lectures and tutorials to sketches.
• Clear response to the text or podcast.
• Originality of work

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a0e7ed6bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a0e7ed6bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a8e7ed6bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619f6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"74e721abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961902","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Herbarium","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

Herbarium of selected plant species, presented in a personal reference book of sketches, annotations about plants, identifying features, overall plant form and potential as a planting design element.

Aim: For each student to develop a personal library of a minimum of 20 plant species.

Procedure: Students will submit two interim submissions to their tutors during class time. These will be assessed on a Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory basis. The final submission in Week 10 is a digital submission of the complete herbarium. Time will be allocated during tutorials for the review and development of the herbarium.

Scope of Work: The herbarium will consist of an A4 booklet of 20 x hand-drawn plant species. Each plant will be depicted through detailed sketches of form, leaves, flowers and fruit. All pages will be fully annotated in accordance with examples provided. The back of the sheet will have a photo of the plant specimen that the student has drawn (photographs cannot be substituted for drawings).

Assessment Criteria:
? Accurate identification of species and their attributes
? Clear textual and graphic communication of plant species and their attributes
? Clear and effective layout and organization of herbarium
? Accurate and sufficient annotations for each species
? Original work: no tracing or copies of the work of others or photographs.
? Evidence of continuous development of herbarium

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a0e7ed6bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a8e7ed6bdb61fc50be4672f5f39619f6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bce721abdb61fc50be4672f5f396191f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Planting Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Conceptual planting plan for a site visited on the field trip, which includes nominating appropriate planting elements, plant species and an overall design, taking into account specific site program.

Aim: To develop knowledge, ability and skills related to the preparation of planting design.

Procedure: Students will develop a detailed planting plan for a site in Waverton Park at least 20 plant species and a range of planting elements. Time will be allocated during tutorials for the development of this plan.

Scope of Work: The Planting Design will consist of one A1 sheet with a site analysis diagram, planting diagram showing the design intention of the planting scheme, planting plan with species annotated, plant schedule, sections and perspective vignettes.

Assessment Criteria:
• Diagrams demonstrate the importance of the site context and site analysis as well as the design process and planting types of the final planting design.
• Fully annotated, detailed planting plan showing layers of plants including trees, understory plants and groundcovers.
• Sections and perspectives illustrate the planting character and the significant plant species.
• Clear and effective layout of the sheet.
• Originality of work

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2201 - Landscape Studio 3 Landform and Planting","description":"

This studio concentrates on two major themes in landscape architecture - landform and planting.  Landform consideration includes investigation into the relationship between topography and natural systems, constructed environments and ecological sustainability.  Design projects involve the manipulation of landform to achieve a range of functions for a real site.  The planting component of this studio builds on plant knowledge and use from previous courses.  Students apply this knowledge to the planting design of a real site, together with consideration of the relationship between landform and plants.  Specific projects may include water sensitive urban design, constructed wetlands, historic perspectives on the use of plants, land art, or the design of transport or recreation precincts.  An integral part of the course is the presentation of a sketch book that demonstrates a wide range of graphic and design skills, and includes examples of design precedents.

contentlets.description: This studio concentrates on two major themes in landscape architecture - landform and planting.  Landform consideration includes investigation into the relationship between topography and natural systems, constructed environments and ecological sustainability.  Design projects involve the manipulation of landform to achieve a range of functions for a real site.  The planting component of this studio builds on plant knowledge and use from previous courses.  Students apply this knowledge to the planting design of a real site, together with consideration of the relationship between landform and plants.  Specific projects may include water sensitive urban design, constructed wetlands, historic perspectives on the use of plants, land art, or the design of transport or recreation precincts.  An integral part of the course is the presentation of a sketch book that demonstrates a wide range of graphic and design skills, and includes examples of design precedents.
contentlets.title: Landscape Studio 3 Landform and Planting

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2202 - Landscape Studio 4 Design Detail: Resolution and Representation","description":"

This studio cultivates an appreciation for the relationship between design detail and site scale design. The studio develops the skill and ability required to develop and resolve design ideas across a range of scales, with students completing a design project from conceptual design through to the detail design stage.
Projects focus on people and place, at the scale of the urban street and/or urban plaza, and integrate the knowledge acquired in landscape construction and documentation courses.
This studio builds students fluency in computer aided design programs required to support detail design resolution and its representation.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"bbe7e1abdb61fc50be4672f5f39619fd","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Concept Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Starting with the final sketch produced by their group charrette, individual students will produce a robust concept design based on challenging and developing the requirements of the brief.  The development of a concept proposal will require each student to explore, through drawing, thier design principles, charrette findings, formal qualities of the site and theories of streets and plazas.

Individual work

Formative feedback, verbal, week 3 (unsatisfactory/satisfactory)

Summative feedback, verbal, week 5 and rubric marking guide

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"37e725abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3fe725abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3fe7e1abdb61fc50be4672f5f39619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"3fe7e1abdb61fc50be4672f5f39619ff","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7fe725abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961905","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Detail Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"
  • Detailed Design: Starting with their concept design, and incorporating feedback received, individual students will develop and  produce a detailed design for the site. Students will use 3D digital software to model, develop and represent their detail design. 
  • Documentation Plans: Students will prepare a set of detailed documentation drawings for their design proposal. 

Individual work

Summative feedback, written with rubric marking guide

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"37e725abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"37e7e1abdb61fc50be4672f5f39619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3fe725abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3fe7e1abdb61fc50be4672f5f39619fe","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bbe725abdb61fc50be4672f5f396190b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Site Investigation/Design Charrette","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"
  • Site Investigations: Student groups investigate the site and its context to produce a series of slides, showcasing what they found, to share with the rest of the class.
  • Design Charrette: Students groups ‘flesh out’ a series of project stakeholders and then assume their personas to reflect their hopes and concerns in a series of quick concepts for the site.

Group work, summative feedback, verbal, week 2 and rubric marking guide for both components.

Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"LAND2251","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2251 - Planting Design at the Landscape Scale","description":"

This course focuses on medium to large scale planting design and green infrastructure and its role in relation to supporting healthy urban environments. Planting design strategies and structures are examined as integral components of urban and suburban landscape systems. Assessment activities focus on developing the skill to describe and assess performance of planting designs across a range of scales and types, including large-scale infrastructure projects, transportation corridors, landscape remediation and regeneration projects, wetland and riparian protection, and initiatives to support landscape resilience and adaptation to climate change.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d5f7a5abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961945","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Identifying and Assessing Green Infrastructure at the Landscape Scale","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Students work in pairs to assess a local, built large scale green infrastructure project. Students identify and describe the attributes of the project in terms of urban and landscape ecological concepts and principles and assess the performance of the project relative to stated aims and government/industry standards. Students present their findings to the class. 

Group work; feedback via rubric. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d5f7a5abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961946","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d5f7a5abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ddf7a5abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961945","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ddf7a5abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961947","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"55f7a5abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961960","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Concepts and Challenges of Urban Ecology in Sydney","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This report takes a case study approach. Students are given a local large scale project for which they identify, assess and analyse how urban ecological principles are applied in practice and propose alternative approaches.

Individual work; feedback via analytical rubric. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d5f7a5abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ddf7a5abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961945","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ddf7a5abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961946","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ddf7a5abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961947","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"59f7a5abdb61fc50be4672f5f396195a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Planting design: concepts and principles","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Short tutorial  exercises aimed at assessing comprehension of key planting design concepts and principles explored in lectures and readings.

Individual work; feedback via marking guides. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d5f7a5abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961946","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d5f7a5abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ddf7a5abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961945","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5df7a5abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961955","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/LAND2251.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2271 - Landscape Design and Documentation 1","description":"

This course introduces students to the principles of documenting landscape projects for construction.  Topics covered include material selection, standard construction practices, introduction to relevant Australian Standards, grading, earthwork calculations, drainage design, detailing and sustainable design and construction practices.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"36f729abdb61fc50be4672f5f396197e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Landscape Documentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Students document a landscape project to professional standards.  The scope of documentation includes demolition, materials and finishes, levels and grading, setout and planting plans. The documentation drawings are developing progressively and submitted as a set. Individual. 

Assessment via analytical rubric and direct comment on drawings.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"36f729abdb61fc50be4672f5f396197f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"36f729abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3ef729abdb61fc50be4672f5f396197e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3ef729abdb61fc50be4672f5f396197f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"76f729abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961989","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Grading Plan and Contour Model","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students prepare contour drawings and models of existing and proposed sites to develop their skill and ability to manipulate land form to acheive desired results. Individual.

Feedback and assessment via analytical rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"36f729abdb61fc50be4672f5f396197f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3ef729abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961980","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7ef729abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961985","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Grading and Landform Exercises","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

A series of  exercises designed to build skills and confidence in manipulating landform by grading a variety of designed landscape elements including paths, roads, swales, platforms, walls, stairs, ramps and terraces. Individual.

Assessment via marking sheets. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"36f729abdb61fc50be4672f5f396197f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3ef729abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961980","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f2f729abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961982","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/LAND2271.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2272 - Landscape Design and Documentation 2","description":"

This course focuses on understanding, interpreting and documenting the structural design and construction techniques for a range of landscape architecture elements and site problems, such as earthworks, site drainage, constructed wetlands, retaining and free-standing walls, pavements, furnishings and small roads and structures. Assessment activities focus on critical interpretation of structural design, and the design, documentation and detailing of a range of materials, elements and structures.


In parallel to this course and its prerequisite, LAND2271, all students are required to complete forty-five days of Industry Work Experience.   Work experience is managed by the Discipline Director for Landscape Architecture; details about the process are available to all students enrolled in the Landscape Architecture Program via the Landscape Architecture Work Experience Moodle page. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9c08a9abdb61fc50be4672f5f396195f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Landscape Detail Design - Project Documentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Working individually, students prepare a prescribed set of construction drawings for a given landscape architecture project. The drawings are completed to professional standards and include technical and material specifications. Drawing types in the project include material and finishes plan, site sections, and details of site features including but not limited to furnishings, plantings, stairs, walls, ramps, and specifications. 

Assessment: online submission; analytical rubric. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1008a9abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1008a9abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1808a9abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1808a9abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a808a9abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961992","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Drawing Exercises: reading and communicating landscape details","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This assessment consists of a set of prescribed drawing exercises undertaken in the weekly tutorials. There are Students are given site plans with preselected landscape features.   Students interpret and redraw these features at a new, prescribed detail scale in plan, section and elevation.  

Feedback via marking rubric. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1008a9abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1008a9abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1808a9abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961961","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"dc08a9abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961963","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Landscape Detail Design in Practice - Case Study Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Working in small groups, students visit selected landscape architecture projects to study the detail design of specified landscape architectural elements. Each group prepares a report which documents , assesses and explains the use of construction techniques, materials, principles of composition, and approaches to environmental sustainability in a local project. The report includes a balance of verbal and graphic material. Tasks include

  • Overview of project context (designers, client, location, date, overall size and type)
  • Measure and document detail design of project in plan, section, elevation
  • Identify, describe and explain the use of materials, composition principles, construction techniques and design standards.
  • Assess application of principles of sustainability and discuss life-cycle issues.
  • Digital presentation to peers

A template is provided for the preparation of the reports and the presentation. Assessment is via oral feedback and analytical rubric. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1008a9abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1008a9abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1808a9abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e808a9abdb61fc50be4672f5f3961968","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/LAND2272.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2301 - Landscape Studio 5 Site Planning: Landscape Systems and Performance","description":"

Students extend their design and analysis abilities by preparing master plans for medium scale sites.  Design proposals are developed as responses to site qualities and a program of uses, with a particular emphasis on the spatial, social and ecological qualities of the landscape.  Students learn to integrate ecological, social and aesthetic considerations as part of the design process and are introduced to the application of design for sustainability.  There is an emphasis on developing, testing and communicating design concepts and extending presentation skills.

contentlets.description: Students extend their design and analysis abilities by preparing master plans for medium scale sites.  Design proposals are developed as responses to site qualities and a program of uses, with a particular emphasis on the spatial, social and ecological qualities of the landscape.  Students learn to integrate ecological, social and aesthetic considerations as part of the design process and are introduced to the application of design for sustainability.  There is an emphasis on developing, testing and communicating design concepts and extending presentation skills.
contentlets.title: Landscape Studio 5 Site Planning: Landscape Systems and Performance

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2302 - Landscape Studio 6 Design with a Complex Program","description":"

In this studio students apply knowledge and skills acquired in previous studios and courses to design projects involving the consideration and resolution of multiple and complex issues.  Projects will have an environmental, social, and aesthetic focus and may include preparing competition entries and/or be interdisciplinary in nature.  Students will refine their professional skills working individually and in small groups.  Presentation skills will be extended to a professional level, incorporating a range of media, including models, and applications using a range of computer software.  A personal design portfolio forms part of this studio, and a satisfactory portfolio is a requirement for completion of this studio.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2311 - Landscape Studio 5: Site Planning - Landscape Systems and Performance","description":"

Students extend their design and analysis abilities by preparing master plans for medium scale sites.  Design proposals are developed as responses to site qualities and a program of uses, with a particular emphasis on the spatial, social and ecological systems of the landscape.  Students learn to integrate ecological, social and aesthetic considerations as part of the design process and are introduced to the application of design for sustainability.  There is an emphasis on developing, testing and communicating design concepts and extending presentation skills

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0c18adabdb61fc50be4672f5f39619b2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

This phase is a group research and analysis exercise which investigates site systems in relation to the studio thematic and precedents. The process and product of this phase form the  context and design focus for the next phase.  Work will be undertaken in groups of 2-5 students. Depending on the cohort each group may focusi their analysis of different aspects of the site and precedent study of exemplar projects related to the studio premise.

 

Analysis and learnings from site and precedent studies will be communicated through drawings and physical models where appropriate. The material will be extensive in scope and its assemblage and presentation rigorous and professional. All drawings / information will be collated as  a shared resource for all to use.

Assessment type: Exhibition, presentation and digital submission to Moodle (group);

Assessment Feedback: Verbal feedback; analytical rubric 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0418adabdb61fc50be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0418adabdb61fc50be4672f5f39619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0418adabdb61fc50be4672f5f39619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0c18adabdb61fc50be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0018adabdb61fc50be4672f5f39619b7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

This is the final iteration of the conceptual design developed in Assessment 2. The conceptual design should clearly communicate strategies and design principles for enhancing the performance of site systems over time, including but not limited to connectivity, biodiversity, accessibility, and  aesthetic experience.  This phase of design also engages with the features, systems and scales important to your concept, including the definition and distribution of program activities and the circulation of people, water, air, flora and fauna. Plans, sections, axonometric drawings, models and perspectives should adequately describe the key components of the scheme and the character and quality of your design concepts. 

Assessment type: presentation and digital submission to Moodle (individual)

Assessment Feedback via verbal feedback and analytical rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0418adabdb61fc50be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0418adabdb61fc50be4672f5f39619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0418adabdb61fc50be4672f5f39619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0c18adabdb61fc50be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1818adabdb61fc50be4672f5f39619c2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

This assesment is an individual enquiry focused on testing and developing a  design concept for your individual project. The design concept is a clear visual statement of the focus and aim of your project. It identifies the past, present and future of the site in terms of cultural context, ecological functions and systems, social activities, and spatial qualities, all in response to the overarching studio brief.  You are encouraged to develop your design concept from a mixture of site, precedent and thematic research informed by your interpretation of how and for whom this landscape will perform over time. 

Assessement by verbal feedback and analytical rubric. 

Verbal feedback, rubric and written feedback.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0418adabdb61fc50be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0418adabdb61fc50be4672f5f39619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0418adabdb61fc50be4672f5f39619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0c18adabdb61fc50be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8c18adabdb61fc50be4672f5f39619bc","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/LAND2311.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2313 - Landscape Studio 7: Design with a Complex Program","description":"

In this studio students apply knowledge and skills acquired in previous studios and courses to design projects involving the consideration and resolution of multiple and complex issues.  Projects will have an environmental, social, and aesthetic focus and may include preparing competition entries and/or be interdisciplinary in nature.  Students will refine their professional skills working individually and in small groups.  Presentation skills will be extended to a professional level, incorporating a range of media, including models, and applications using a range of computer software.  A personal design portfolio forms part of this studio, and a satisfactory portfolio is a requirement for successful completion.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2401 - Landscape Studio 7 Urban Landscape Design","description":"

An exploration of the relationships within the fabric of the urban environment including concepts of city functions and the analysis of disparate parts of the city with physical design being the primary focus. Context and place, history and theory are considered as well as analytical techniques. Design studios, lectures and seminars. This course generates the urban design context for the Graduating Project undertaken in LAND2402 Landscape Studio 8. This studio culminates in the preparation of individual design proposals which form the basis of the graduating project in Session 2.

contentlets.description: An exploration of the relationships within the fabric of the urban environment including concepts of city functions and the analysis of disparate parts of the city with physical design being the primary focus. Context and place, history and theory are considered as well as analytical techniques. Design studios, lectures and seminars. This course generates the urban design context for the Graduating Project undertaken in LAND2402 Landscape Studio 8. This studio culminates in the preparation of individual design proposals which form the basis of the graduating project in Session 2.
contentlets.title: Landscape Studio 7 Urban Landscape Design

Students are called upon to employ all the knowledge, skill and understanding they have gained in previous years and to explore issues and approaches in design which are of particular interest to them. The graduating design project follows from LAND2401 Landscape Studio 7 and involves sketch design and detailed design development. Graduating project is related to the suburban, urban or rural environment. The studio will critically assess aspects of theory through design speculation.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2411 - Landscape Studio 8: Urban Landscape Design","description":"

This course investigates the interdependency of landscape and urban morphology by testing large-scale urban design propositions within a particular landscape and responding to current government planning documents and aspirations for the site. Students learn about urbanisation and site issues through lectures and guest presentations by relevant stakeholders and practitioners. This information, along with site analysis and precedent studies, enables students to develop urban landscape design frameworks that respond sensitively and creatively to the issues facing the site. This course generates the urban design context for the individual project developed in LAND2412 Landscape Studio 9.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"092865ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961940","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Precedent Studies","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

This project prepares students for the tasks of designing streets, city blocks and neighbourhoods and understanding their relationships within an urban design framework.

Groups assess two built urban spatial types/scales such as streets, city blocks and/or precincts under a set analytical template for comparative purposes.

Submitted digitally and pinned up as comparative resource each studio.

Groups are marked for individual components within the analytical template.

Feedback is provided in writing with comments and rubric for each of the individual components within the analytical template and verbally in following studio sessions where precedents studies are pinned up.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"052865ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961942","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0d2865ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961943","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1d2865ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961950","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Analysis, Goals & Objectives and Main Moves","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

The site analysis leads to a detailed rationale for the subsequent design process. Site conditions will be evaluated against the aims and aspirations of a current large-scale project/proposition.

Groups prepare a detailed site, catchment and metropolitan analysis, establish project goals and objectives and propose main design moves.

Feedback is provided verbally during presentations in a design jury setting and in writing with comments and rubric

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"052865ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961943","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0d2865ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961941","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0d2865ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961942","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0d2865ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961943","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"512865ebdb61fc50be4672f5f396194b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Urban Landscape Design Framework and Precinct Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

An urban landscape design framework is prepared with clear reference to the site analysis and key objectives that provides a compelling vision for the project in relation to the site’s immediate and metropolitan context.

A more detailed precinct/area is developed to illustrate the urban landscape design proposition in more detail showing public domain conditions, character and relationships with ecological, social and transport systems as well as built form.

Feedback is provided verbally during presentations in a design jury setting and in writing with comments and rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"052865ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961942","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0d2865ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961941","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0d2865ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961942","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0d2865ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961943","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c12865ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961945","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/LAND2411.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2412 - Landscape Studio 9: Urban Public Domain","description":"

This course investigates landscape architectural knowledge and approaches across a range of scales including district, neighbourhood, city block and city space. The course will explore and refine skills in resolving public domain areas through the lens of particular landscape architectural concerns such as ecological and social processes. Theoretical knowledge underpinning the selected topics explored are developed concurrently in LAND2421 Contemporary Theory and Research.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1228a5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961983","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design Research Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

The final project in this course is a Design Research Proposal for the Graduating Studio in Term 3. Research by design is part of a wider trend to value the discovery that is possible through the activity of creative practice. This project will outline the scope, including a research question, the site and the methods of the proposed investigation.

Submission format will be slideshow presentation. Feedback will be provided in writing with comments and marking rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1228a5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961984","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1a28a5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961983","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1e28a5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f396198f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thematic Exploration","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This project is an open-ended ideas exploration. It explores possible design directions that expand both the student’s knowledge and the disciplinary topic itself. It provides the opportunity to step away from pre-conceived trajectories and experiment with multiple topics, ideas and ways of drawing. This is an opportunity to “go broad” and explore potentially unforeseen directions before settling on a firmer approach in the final project of this course; the Design Research Proposal.

Submission format will be a standalone poster presentation with the most constructive and generative drawings selected for a slideshow presentation. Feedback will be provided verbally after the presentation and in writing with comments and marking rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1228a5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961985","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1a28a5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1a28a5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961984","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d228a5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f396198b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Public Domain Thematic Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students prepare new brief/objectives based on newly acquired theoretical knowledge from parallel course LAND2421.

Site analysis under lens of new brief/topic.

Articulate measures/tasks/research necessary to meet brief in relation to site conditions.

Undertake iterative design process testing application of theoretical concepts.

Demonstrate design process undertaken to achieve objectives in brief.

Feedback is provided verbally during presentations in a design jury setting and in writing with comments and rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1228a5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961985","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1a28a5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1a28a5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961984","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d628a5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f3961986","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/LAND2412.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2413 - Landscape Studio 10: Landscape Architecture Graduation Studio","description":"

Students are called upon to employ the knowledge, skills and understanding they have gained in previous years and to explore issues and approaches in design which are of particular interest to them. The graduating design project follows from LAND2412 Landscape Studio 9 and involves sketch design and detailed design development. Graduating project is related to the suburban, urban or rural environment. The studio will critically assess aspects of theory through design speculation.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"db28e5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f39619cd","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Brief","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

A Project Brief is prepared to guide each student’s individual Graduating Studio project. In practice, briefs are a written and illustrated documents that outline what will be explored during the planning and/or design of a landscape intervention or urban proposition. It articulates the aims of the project and expectations on what will be delivered at the end of the design process.

As a self-directed studio, students write a brief for themselves to set out the aims of the project to be undertaken and the thinking behind it. 

Feedback

Verbal feedback is provided during the presentation

Written feedback sheets are provided after teaching staff have discussed and moderated all submissions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9328e5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f39619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9b28e5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f39619cf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9b28e5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f39619d0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5328e5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f39619d2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Graduating Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

Students present the outcome of their individual landscape design exploration for a site of their choice within the study area. The chosen site should draw on the group structure plan prepared in LAND2411 and be based on their design proposition prepared in LAND2412.

The students self-led program of design investigations should result in a robust, rigorous, highly resolved and accomplished individual design outcome. The outcome must demonstrate each student’s awareness and engagement with the relevant contemporary theories driving their design thesis and facing urban landscape architectural design. Evidence of design process should be clearly demonstrated through the course of the term and in the final design submission.

Feedback

Verbal feedback is provided during the presentation.  

Written feedback sheets are provided after teaching staff have discussed and moderated all submissions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9328e5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f39619cf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9328e5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f39619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9b28e5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f39619ce","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9b28e5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f39619cf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9b28e5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f39619d0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5b28e5ebdb61fc50be4672f5f39619dc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Interim Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

The Interim Review will comprise a review of your preliminary design concepts and will assess the development of your project in a formal, internal critique session. The work will be presented through study models, sketch drawings, diagrams and a brief verbal presentation.

Feedback

Verbal feedback is provided during the presentation.  

Written feedback sheets are provided after teaching staff have discussed and moderated all submissions.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND2421 - Contemporary Landscape Theory and Research","description":"

Students develop in depth knowledge of contemporary landscape design through a detailed review of current projects, built works and writings. Students will investigate and test current theories of design in landscape architecture, through the critical analysis of recent work. Current concerns in landscape design will be reviewed against the trajectory of twentieth century modernism. Development of the critical methodological and stylistic skills involved in researching, writing and presenting essays, theses, articles, papers and reports. Each student researches and prepares a literature review, a seminar presentation and a research paper.

contentlets.description: Students develop in depth knowledge of contemporary landscape design through a detailed review of current projects, built works and writings. Students will investigate and test current theories of design in landscape architecture, through the critical analysis of recent work. Current concerns in landscape design will be reviewed against the trajectory of twentieth century modernism. Development of the critical methodological and stylistic skills involved in researching, writing and presenting essays, theses, articles, papers and reports. Each student researches and prepares a literature review, a seminar presentation and a research paper.
contentlets.title: Contemporary Landscape Theory and Research

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND7101 - Master Landscape Studio 1: Site Planning - Landscape Performance and Site Design","description":"

This is the first design studio in Stream A of the MLArch.  It develops design thinking and skills by requiring students to integrate programmatic requirements into the design process.  Design projects focus on landscape systems to address the spectrum of contemporary site planning concerns: access, circulation, water quality and drainage, social equity, biodiversity and resilience.  Students develop skills in analytical and conceptual thinking by working on medium scale sites, and the ability to test and integrate ecological, social, aesthetic and temporal aspects of landscape performance into the design process.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND7102 - Master Landscape Studio 2: Design with a Complex Program","description":"

In this course, students will extend their design and analysis abilities by preparing master plans for medium scale sites. Design proposals are developed as responses to site qualities and a program of uses, with a particular emphasis on the spatial, social, and ecological systems of the landscape. Students will learn to integrate ecological, social, and aesthetic considerations as part of the design process and re introduced to the application of design for sustainability. There is an emphasis on the performance of the design concepts tested.

Assessment Description and Feedback Process

We will aim to provide clear and timely feedback within two weeks of an assessment task.

Peer assessment

Generate three different site design concepts related to the investigations carried out in Project 1; respond to sustainable design goals and addressing three site planning issues, eg. people/place issues, planting arrangements, built form and microclimatic conditions. 

Assessment Description and Feedback Process

Weekly desk critiques with tutors during the design concept development process

We will aim to provide clear and timely feedback within two weeks of an assessment task.

Written, verbal and rubric feedback from tutors at presentation of work.

Weekly desk crits with tutors during design development process.

Verbal presentation of final design proposal to a panel including course convener, tutor(s), and external reviewers.

Written, verbal and rubric feedback at final presentation of work.

We will aim to provide clear and timely feedback within two weeks of an assessment task.
