Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND7121 - People Place Design","description":"

People, Place, Design provides an introduction to the extensive body of environment-behaviour research and theory on people’s relationship to place. Students will gain an understanding of the needs of specific users in the design of public spaces in which they live, work and play. Individual perceptions of shared and personal space, universal design and social inclusion will be explored, along with considering how planning and design contribute to social and environmental sustainability in communities. Most of the ideas and concepts discussed will be relevant to all environments and all types of design but for this course the focus will be on public spaces and environments in the public domain.


The course will look at concepts that relate to people and their needs. This will include special population groups, such as children and young people, the elderly, people with disabilities, and people from different cultural backgrounds. It will also look at different environments through a social lens including the public domain; open space and parks in urban settings; the streetscape as a significant environment for interaction and ‘liveability’ of a city; environmental design factors that enable or discourage participation and sustainability in communities. The third part of the course will look at the implications of using an environment-behaviour lens as part of design and planning practice, discussing concepts such as public involvement and participatory planning and design and providing opportunities for the class to engage in some of these processes and methods.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a3386debdb61fc50be4672f5f3961919","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: How does your profession impact people?","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

In this self-reflection assignment, students will reflect on the many ways their profession makes an impact potentially on the everyday lives of people. Their written submissions will be assessed based on the sophistication of their reflection, the structure of their writing, the overall effectiveness of their communication, and the presentation of their ideas. 

Feedback on the assessment tasks will be given in two weeks after submission. It will be online feedback on individual assignments using a rubric in Turnitin. There will be plenty of opportunities to question feedback during the tutorial time and by email.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a7386debdb61fc50be4672f5f396191b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"af386debdb61fc50be4672f5f396191b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"67386debdb61fc50be4672f5f396191d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Two in-class activities centred on behaviour mapping and public involvement","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Feedback on the assessment tasks will be given orally through the in-class discussion. The tutors will comment on the quality of the data collected, the sophistication of the data analysis and the reflection on the task. There will be plenty of opportunities to question feedback during class time.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a7386debdb61fc50be4672f5f396191b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"af386debdb61fc50be4672f5f396191b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ef386debdb61fc50be4672f5f3961920","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Social challenges and environmental solutions","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

Students will work in teams of 5-6 people to identify a social challenge. Students will choose a pressing social issue, research it, understand it and recognise the role that the physical environment plays in it. They will complete part 1 individually in which they research their selected topic thoroughly to enable them to develop a sound design intervention in part 2 as a group. In part 2, the groups will develop an environmental or technological intervention that would assist the issue. The value of part 1 (individual) is 30% and the value of part 2 (group) is 30%, both make up 60% which is the value of this assessment.  

Their individual submissions in part 1 will be assessed based on the quality of their research and their writing, referencing and presentation of ideas. Students will present their proposed intervention (part 2) via a Peche Kuche developed by all members of each group. Part 2 will be assessed based on the depth and resolution of the new idea, quality of solution and its usability for the community, the preparedness of the group for the presentation, evidence of good teamwork, and clear and strong graphic presentation. 

Feedback on the assessment tasks will be given in two weeks after submission. The feedback on the assignments will be online using a rubric. The group submission folder will use a team evaluation plugin to take each members' contribution into account. There will be plenty of opportunities to question feedback during the tutorial time and by email.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a7386debdb61fc50be4672f5f396191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a7386debdb61fc50be4672f5f396191b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"af386debdb61fc50be4672f5f396191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"af386debdb61fc50be4672f5f396191b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f7386debdb61fc50be4672f5f3961924","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/LAND7121.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND7151 - Planting Design at the Landscape Scale","description":"

This postgraduate course builds students’ knowledge of plants and plant communities and focuses on plants as components of urban ecological landscape patterns at the site, landscape and metropolitan scales. It examines the role of plants in various situations, for example, in landscape remediation and regeneration, planning for climate change resilience, and serving as ‘green infrastructure’, and protecting riparian and wetland areas. The course involves excursions to local sites, and students are asked to contribute to the cost of these excursions. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4648212fdb61fc50be4672f5f396194f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Planting design: concepts and principles","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Short tutorial exercises aimed at assessing comprehension of key planting design concepts and principles explored in lectures and readings.

Individual work; feedback via marking guides.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c648212fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c648212fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961951","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5e48212fdb61fc50be4672f5f396195d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Proposal Identifying and Assessing Green Infrastructure at the Landscape Scale","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Students work in pairs to assess a local, built large scale green infrastructure project. Students identify and describe the attributes of the project in terms of urban and landscape ecological concepts and principles. Students assess the performance of the project relative to stated aims and government/industry standards and develop alternative strategies to optimise capacity for adaptation and resiliency to the impacts of climate change. The findings are submitted as a report and as a verbal presentation to  the class.

Group work; feedback via rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c648212fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c648212fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961951","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ce48212fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ce48212fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961951","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8248212fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961958","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Concepts and Challenges of Urban Ecology in Sydney","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This report takes a case study approach. Students are given a local large scale project for which they identify, assess and analyse how urban ecological principles are applied in practice and propose alternative approaches.

Individual work; feedback via analytical rubric.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND7152 - Landscape Theory and Practice: Urban Ecology and Landscape Design","description":"

In this course you will examine the influence of urban ecology on the practice of landscape architecture over the last 50 years. You will explore both the theoretical and practical applications of urban ecology principles and concepts as applied to established, regenerated and new urban landscapes. 


You will draw on both international and local case studies to map the trajectory of key ideas, projects and designers which influenced changes in the role of ecology in relation to landscape design. Topics include: succession, adaptation and resilience; novel ecosystems, landscape ecology, ecological urbanism, and landscape urbanism.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"aa48212fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619bb","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Seminar Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

 Students investigate potential applications of urban ecological concepts and principles to a new project.  The seminar requires a balance of speculation about future possibilities, consideration of the historical trajectory of urban landscapes, and the ability to engage others in discussion. 

Visual and verbal presentation, fifteen minutes in length supported by a <1000 word discussion paper and annotated bibliography. Feedback via seminar discussion, written rubric, and self and peer evaluation of group work.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6248212fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6248212fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6a48212fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6a48212fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619bd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a648212fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619c6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Comparative Case Studies ","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

In this essay students compare two case studies to assess the application of theories and concepts of urban ecology to the design of urban landscapes. 

1500 word illustrated essay, with feedback via analytical rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6248212fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6a48212fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6a48212fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619bd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e248212fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619bf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Observing and recording the designed urban landscape","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Ongoing recording of observations regarding the integration and application of urban ecological concepts and principles to Sydney's landscapes. 

This is a visual diary with eight entries of approximately 250 words and a mix of photographs and drawings. Interim peer review, formative verbal feedback and a written rubric for final submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6a48212fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619bd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ee48212fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619c3","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/LAND7152.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}
contentlets.description:
In this course you will examine the influence of urban ecology on the practice of landscape architecture over the last 50 years. You will explore both the theoretical and practical applications of urban ecology principles and concepts as applied to established, regenerated and new urban landscapes. 

You will draw on both international and local case studies to map the trajectory of key ideas, projects and designers which influenced changes in the role of ecology in relation to landscape design. Topics include: succession, adaptation and resilience; novel ecosystems, landscape ecology, ecological urbanism, and landscape urbanism.
contentlets.title: Landscape Theory and Practice: Urban Ecology and Landscape Design

In this course you will focus on the observation, interpretation and representation of a landscape catchment at several different scales and develop the technical skills to investigate, analyse and synthesise the complex interrelationship between geology, climate, soils, hydrology, vegetation, fauna and humans. You will be introduced to advanced concepts of sustainability, biodiversity, habitat fragmentation, and landscape ecology.  Through a range of assessment tasks you will record, analyse and interpret the landscape using inventory, survey, mapping, reporting and presentation techniques associated with the practice of landscape architecture.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND7201 - Master Landscape Studio 3: The Public Realm","description":"

Landscape architects are most often engaged in the planning and design of open spaces in the public realm including streets, paths, plazas, parks, waterways and coastal edges. 


Through five themes, being: typology, interface, strategies, policy and people, this course examines the varied demands placed on the public realm in an urban context and equips students with approaches to the strategic planning and design of public realm at the precinct scale. 


During the course students will develop knowledge in the spatial and functional requirements and user expectations of a range of public realm types and their relationship to each other and built form. Students will learn approaches to public realm policy, strategies and design that responds to various spatial and stakeholder conditions.

contentlets.description:
Landscape architects are most often engaged in the planning and design of open spaces in the public realm including streets, paths, plazas, parks, waterways and coastal edges. 

Through five themes, being: typology, interface, strategies, policy and people, this course examines the varied demands placed on the public realm in an urban context and equips students with approaches to the strategic planning and design of public realm at the precinct scale. 

During the course students will develop knowledge in the spatial and functional requirements and user expectations of a range of public realm types and their relationship to each other and built form. Students will learn approaches to public realm policy, strategies and design that responds to various spatial and stakeholder conditions.
contentlets.title: Master Landscape Studio 3: The Public Realm

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND7202 - Master Landscape Studio 4: Constructed Ecologies","description":"

This studio approaches the designed landscape from an ecological perspective. The design process in the studio relies on ecological knowledge to inform, inspire, and shape the designed landscape. Different types of constructed ecologies are examined, including urban parks, constructed wetlands; green infrastructure; urban forests; green roofs and walls. Studio projects focus on the catchment scale and take landscape design as a critical and creative means of improving ecological and social performance. Skills in landform manipulation, wetland construction, and planting for climate and habitat health are integrated into the design agenda. Projects incorporate digital technologies as a means of testing design propositions.

Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"LAND7211","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND7211 - Case Studies in Landscape Architecture","description":"

The course is an introduction to the analysis and design of urban landscapes, focusing on the spatial quality, scale and texture of cities. Urban form is studied as a complex system of building types, civic space, infrastructures and ecosystems. Students critically analyse cities as expressions of human responses to environmental conditions and natural processes. The course also emphasises the role of landscape architecture and planning in sustainable/green cities. Assessment tasks include quizzes, national and international case study analysis and a research essay.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2e58a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961914","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"A3 - Places in urban landscapes (Individual task)","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Illustrated Research essay

The objective of assignment A3 is to produce an illustrated essay to integrate the Urban Landscape Atlas. The essay will be based on the development of previous research findings assignment A2.

The essay will contain images, maps, diagrams and describe, argue, discuss hypothesis and research questions. Essay’s content: Min 2500 max 3000 words, excluding references, footnotes (if any), captions, tables, and titles. Refer to tutorial T6, T7 and T8 for this section.

Assignment A3 will be uploaded on Moodle and will receive written feedback and rubrics.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a658a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961916","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a658a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ae58a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961915","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ae58a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961916","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3a58a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f396192c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"A1 - In-class Quiz (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Theory and practice of urban landscape design

Assignment A1 is covering the activities, lectures and readings in tutorials T0, T1 and T2. Additional materials will be provided during class to integrate the tutorials. 

This assignment is aimed at retrieving and refreshing your meta-knowledge on landscape architecture history and city planning from previous courses.

A1 will be marked online on the base of the results of a multiple-choice and open-end questions quiz.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a658a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ae58a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961915","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6e58a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961918","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"A2 - The urban landscape atlas (Group work)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Urban analysis

The students will produce an Urban Landscapes Atlas as a bound collection of maps of urban landscapes in Australia and around the world.  Each team will focus on the comparison of five cities and examine their urban development in relation to pre-existing landscapes and environmental conditions, including local climate, topography, hydrography, latitude, orientation, etc.

Assignment A2 will be handed over and uploaded online on Moodle in PDF format. Final deliverables will receive written feedback and rubrics on Moodle. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a658a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961916","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ae58a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961916","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"be58a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961928","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/LAND7211.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND7221 - Advanced Urban Landscape Visualisation","description":"

This course introduces students to the visualisation of complex landscape systems and dynamics, using visual scripting interfaces and technologies such as Rhino, Grasshopper, Photoshop, 3D Studio Max, and the HoloLens. Students explore design decisions by simulating and evaluating changes to environmental conditions with a focus on landform, hydrology and planting.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5758a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619a3","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Reflecting on and Communicating your Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

a. Axonometric Artwork

Communicate all the layers of complexity of your design using an axonometric artwork.

b.Animation

Communicate your design using a 3 minute animation

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9358a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619a4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9358a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9358a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9b58a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619a5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1758a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619a7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Analysing an Environmental System","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Analyse and describe an environmental system using diagrams, sketches, images, and/or gifs.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9b58a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619a4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9358a52fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619ad","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Designing an Environmental System","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

a. Concept Design

Delineate your topological system using sketches, diagrams, images and gifs

b. Preliminary Design

Critically analyse and describe your first set of experiments and results using sketches diagrams, images and gifs.

c. Design Development

Describe how and why you implemented our process after the first set of experiments and results. Analyse and describe your second set of experiments and results using sketches, diagrams, images and gifs

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND7272 - Landscape Technology 1: Landscape Performance (Materials and Fabrication)","description":"

This course is a co-requisite for LAND 7202: Master Landscape Studio 4: Constructed Ecologies. The course develops the knowledge and ability to address the technological challenges of constructed ecologies, their construction systems and methods, and their performance. The material focus is on landform, stormwater and vegetation.  Techniques of grading, earthworks, and drainage are explored.  Digital modeling and fabirication are used to increase student's capacity to communicate and test design options; the digital model developed in this course are integrated into the con-current studio project.

Studio","description":"

This studio provides with you with a learning experience in a regional landscape context. You will draw on your knowledge and skills to engage with a challenging social issue in a real-world landscape planning and/or design situation. You will engage in community participation processes to investigate diverse challenges faced by regional communities as they plan and design for sustainable landscapes. The studio will typically include a public exhibition and/or a publication component. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2dde8c67db3c3410be4672f5f396190e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Public presentation and/or performance","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Review, reflect, and revise scenario from Assessment 2. Design proposal and present to community through oral reports and/or public exhibition. Feedback will provided through rubrics, oral and written comments.

Students engage in a  process of  scholarly exploration through contemporary landscape architectural works and theories in relation to  the design process and design research. Students develop skills in research design and methods, critical review, research by design, documentation and writing. Students prepare an achievable, theoretically-informed research proposal which forms the basis of the design work in the  Capstone Studio.

Peer review

This course is the first stage of the capstone experience.  Students work in groups to identify,compile, map and assess background information for the capstone theme, selected by the course convenor.  The group report establish critical contextual data, theory and precedents for their individual projects. 

Peer discussion and review. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5468e52fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619e2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5468e52fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619e3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a068e52fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619eb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Interim Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students situate their capstone project by engaging in site and problem specific research. The report is verbal and graphic and  includes a a draft literature review, case studies, design principles and strategies. 

Seminar presentation and discussion

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND7312 - Masters Landscape Studio: Capstone Part 1","description":"

Capstone 1 is the first phase of the culminating design studio in the UNSW MLArch. Together with LAND 7311 and LAND7313, this course forms an independent, year-long research and design process.  Students initiate their design proposition in LAND 7311, setting their own design research agenda within the structure of a collective studio project.  Students identify a theme or issue relevant to contemporary practice which serves as the framework for a design-based research project. Each student works closely with staff and peers in the studio to develop and test their design propositions. 


In this studio, students consider how metropolitan landscape systems have informed and shaped urban settlement, and vice versa. In a suite of directed design projects, students are given a future scenario which guides and challenges their design thinking in terms of scale and complexity. During the course students will develop knowledge of the relationship between landscape systems and urban settlements and extend their abilities to plan and design landscapes as integrated components of city and metropolitan systems.

contentlets.description:
Capstone 1 is the first phase of the culminating design studio in the UNSW MLArch. Together with LAND 7311 and LAND7313, this course forms an independent, year-long research and design process.  Students initiate their design proposition in LAND 7311, setting their own design research agenda within the structure of a collective studio project.  Students identify a theme or issue relevant to contemporary practice which serves as the framework for a design-based research project. Each student works closely with staff and peers in the studio to develop and test their design propositions. 

In this studio, students consider how metropolitan landscape systems have informed and shaped urban settlement, and vice versa. In a suite of directed design projects, students are given a future scenario which guides and challenges their design thinking in terms of scale and complexity. During the course students will develop knowledge of the relationship between landscape systems and urban settlements and extend their abilities to plan and design landscapes as integrated components of city and metropolitan systems.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND7313 - Masters Landscape Studio: Capstone Part 2","description":"

This studio takes landscape systems at the city scale as a framework for design.  Landscape systems span and shape cities and urban regions, as well as political boundaries. Landscape systems include geology, hydrology, vegetation, habitat, transportation, open space, infrastructure and built form. All of these systems exert environmental impacts which affect quality of life at many scales-- the metropolitan, the city, the precinct, the neighbourhood as well as local streets and spaces.


In this studio, students consider how metropolitan landscape systems have informed and shaped urban settlement, and vice versa. In a suite of directed design projects, students are given a future scenario which guides and challenges their design thinking in terms of scale and complexity. During the course students will develop knowledge of the relationship between landscape systems and urban settlements and extend their abilities to plan and design landscapes as integrated components of city and metropolitan systems.  

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7d68692fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961925","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Interim Design Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Presentation of a design that shows a critical position toward all aspects of the design brief, and is sufficiently developed to illustrate cohesive ideas and allow for robust discussion and feedback. Students will present to a select panel. Feedback via verbal comments and an analytical rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b168692fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b168692fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b968692fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961926","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b968692fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961927","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4268692fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961935","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Design Return Brief (From Research to Design)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Production of a return brief focused on transforming the undertaken research from previous course work into a direction / approach for the design going forward.
Feedback will be via verbal and written comments provided by the course convener assessed against the assessment requirements with consideration of particular requirements of each student.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b168692fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b168692fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b968692fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961926","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b968692fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961927","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7968692fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961929","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Final Design Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

A highly resolved design completed to a professional standard. Students will present to a panel of experts. The panel will provide verbal comments; staff will assess against a rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b168692fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b168692fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b968692fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961926","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b968692fdb61fc50be4672f5f3961927","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f568692fdb61fc50be4672f5f396192f","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/LAND7313.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}
contentlets.keywords: landscape architecture,urban planning; urban landscape design; environmental planning
contentlets.description:
This studio takes landscape systems at the city scale as a framework for design.  Landscape systems span and shape cities and urban regions, as well as political boundaries. Landscape systems include geology, hydrology, vegetation, habitat, transportation, open space, infrastructure and built form. All of these systems exert environmental impacts which affect quality of life at many scales-- the metropolitan, the city, the precinct, the neighbourhood as well as local streets and spaces.

In this studio, students consider how metropolitan landscape systems have informed and shaped urban settlement, and vice versa. In a suite of directed design projects, students are given a future scenario which guides and challenges their design thinking in terms of scale and complexity. During the course students will develop knowledge of the relationship between landscape systems and urban settlements and extend their abilities to plan and design landscapes as integrated components of city and metropolitan systems.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND7315 - Professional Practice for Landscape Architects ","description":"

You will be introduced to the requirements that address the professional practice and registration as a Landscape Architect in Australia. Topics include ethical, contractual, legal and business responsibilities, code of conduct, professional standards, client relationships, consultancy, project procurement, contracts and project management. Course delivery is supported by guest lectures from industry leaders, organised and facilitated by student teams.

Project brief and tender. Students will work individually to prepare a Tender Proposal to undertake a landscape master planning project for a specific site.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"LAND7321 - Landscape Technology 2","description":"

The course explores innovative landscape materials and emerging approaches to design development and construction. Students develop their capacity to transform landscape design concepts into tangible and workable landscape proposals through the methods and techniques of design development. Creative exploration of material properties is introduced alongside traditional systems of landscape construction and industry standards.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2a68692fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619e4","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Sketchbook (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Intent : This assignment evaluates the design process and capacity of students to construct a body of knowledge about landscape approaches, technologies, innovative materials and construction techniques based on the discussions and work-in-progress conducted during lectures and tutorial sessions. It also assesses the capacity of students to illustrate this knowledge and visually communicate exploratory/preliminary ideas through two- and three-dimensional hand-drawings and sketches.
Type : Written commentary / design / drawing / plan / sketch
Mode : Individual
Weight : PART A. Detail drawings 15%
PART B. Lecture and tutorials 10%

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2268692fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619e6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2a68692fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619e6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2a68692fdb61fc50be4672f5f39619ed","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Case study in landscape technologies and materials (group report)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Intent : This assignment will develop your skills in evaluating, identifying, investigating, and generating information relating to innovative landscape materials, approaches and technologies using case studies.
Type : Written commentary / drawing / plan / sketch
Groupwork : Group
Weight : 30%
Scope/tasks : Students will consider and undertake the following:
- Students will work in groups to analyse a case study (students can choose the same case study analysed in LAND7211: Case studies in Landscape course) in terms of high-performance landscape materials, approaches and technologies.
- This report should include the following sections:
a. Brief introduction and site analysis of the case study including: location, key areas within the case study in detail, use/function of the site and key climatic conditions.
b. A detailed analysis (including data) of the performance of materials (durability, sustainability, buildability, cost, maintenance, etc.), construction technologies, and design approaches implemented in the case study using sketches, details, diagrams, etc. At the end of the analysis, students must identify possible design flaws/inconsistencies or issues/problems and potential areas of improvement.
c. Suggestions or recommendations on innovative materials and design/ construction technologies that could be implemented to improve or correct the design issues and inconsistencies identified in previous section. Students can use sketches, diagrams or digital models to illustrate the solutions that they are proposing. A written justification and explanation of the proposed technologies and materials should be included in this section.
d. A short conclusion highlighting key findings and suggestions.

Portfolio of innovative technologies, approaches and materials (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

Intent : This assignment will further the initial observations and research into innovative landscape materials construction technologies and design approaches with direct reference to application to concurrent studio project. Background research should include environmental and social context and conditions; intended performance parameters, and material and detail specification. Digital modelling and simulations can be incorporated into this portfolio as part of the performative analysis of proposed technical solutions.
Type : Written commentary / design / drawing / plan / sketch
Mode : Individual
Weight : PART A. Final oral presentations (10%)
PART B. Final portfolio (35%)

contentlets.description: The course explores innovative landscape materials and emerging approaches to design development and construction. Students develop their capacity to transform landscape design concepts into tangible and workable landscape proposals through the methods and techniques of design development. Creative exploration of material properties is introduced alongside traditional systems of landscape construction and industry standards.
